expert_substantive_messages.author: oaklandmatt
expert_substantive_messages.content:
The landscape for pitching songs has changed dramatically in the last decade. It still exists, but it has shrunk to the point where even the top level writers can't rely on it as much.

This is simply because many more people can write songs and make demos quickly. This results in two things: the market is flooded with songs, and artists who used to rely on pitch songs are now writing (or co-writing) the majority of their material.

Many songs that used to be sent to an artist are now brought into the room and finished with the artist themselves. Like, you'd pitch a chorus or a 3/4 finished song to an artist and finish with them on the spot.

The genres where pitching songs still predominates are country the (industry is still writer–driven), EDM (many artists are performers who do not write or produce), and pop (but they're mostly just looking for HITS).

Another consequence of this shrinking pitch landscape is that the projects that need "outside" songs are much more gate-kept by people in the industry. In country, there are publishers and labels that generally source the songs. In pop, labels and executive producers (of specific projects) tend to be the gate keepers, and in EDM it is a similar combo.

So, to answer your question directly, the best way to pitch songs is to build direct relationships with artists or go through the various business people who gate-keep the process.

To advise you based on your question: make incredible records with your friends, peers, and the people around you, and get visibility that way. Hustle like crazy and use every moment of new visibility as a stepping stone to get in the mix with the larger music community. Ultimately you probably sign a publishing deal and sing with a manager where you get business representatives to help guide you and connect you further.

As with all things music, if you actually really for real make A+ records, people will find you. It's just that this is a lot harder than people think.

expert_substantive_messages.author: BatMeckley
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Honestly, that line is a bit over blown. It’s more “oh the chorus is louder, let’s knock it back a click or two on the input so it doesn’t distort”

We were usually recording songs in fairly small sections, making sure to get the details right. There wasn’t a lot of jedi like fader riding. On very rare occasions if I knew there was going to be a huge dynamic shift I’d reach out and grab the output fader, but I can probably count on one hand how many times I’ve had to do that.

We were fairly conservative on the 1176 on the way in, largely cause you can’t un crunch a vocal that’s been over compressed, but once the vocal was in PT it would be hit by just irresponsible levels of compression and limiting. Like goes against how virtually every “expert” online would tell you how to do it. Most people would tell you the solo’d tracks would sound bad, but as part of the song their impact is objectively unarguable

expert_substantive_messages.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_substantive_messages.content:
.
Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively)

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

expert_substantive_messages.author: Slow Hand
expert_substantive_messages.content:
It's a big topic, but gain staging is about finding the optimal amount of gain at every stage of the recording and mixing process.

Good gain staging allows you to get the best fidelity out of a recording by preventing things from creating unwanted distortion or amplifying unwanted noise. **OR** if you are *seeking* some distortion and compression it's about turning up the gain enough to give you the amount that you're seeking from your tools.

Gain staging is something to be considered at all steps of the production process. For example:

*1. How loud is an amplifier turned up in the room? Is the microphone being blow out by it?

2. How high is the gain on a microphone preamp and is it at risk of clipping if the performer plays loudly?

3. Is the gain so low that when I turn a signal up later on the noise floor will rise with it?

4. If I'm recording to tape, am I recording quiet enough that it won't saturate the signal, or do I want for the signal to slam the tape and be saturated?

5. How loud is an individual channel in a DAW? Is it making the channel clip?

6. How loud is a signal that's being sent into a piece of hardware or a plugin? Am I distorting the circuitry at all?

7. Is my signal coming in so hot that it makes a compressor react way too hard?

8. How loud is the entire track I'm mixing? Is the limiter crushing the dynamics in an unwanted way? Or am I hitting it just with just enough level to get a certain flavor of pumping and clipping?

9. Is my final mix going to hit digital zero and create unwanted clipping?*

So gain staging is not a single thing, but a series of choices that are made every step of the way around how you manage the "voltage" of your signals. Together these choices all add up to a mix that "breathes" well and is free of excessive or unwanted distortion.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Rollmottle
expert_substantive_messages.content:
I have a couple distinct phases of my workflow. The “technical” phase let’s call it, is all about letting my brain objectively search for the very specific kinds of things that are distracting within the mix at hand. This is much more of a thinking and corrective process than it is a feeling one, even though feeling and taste is 100% involved. This part of the process is to get the mix on a more solid foundation if needed.

The next phase is where I want to actively NOT be thinking at all. This is why I do the first part separately. I want to be FEELING the music in this phase and not be taken out of it by the vocal resonance at 1.8k at 1:35 in the bridge. I want to turn that part of my brain off so I can focus on the music, the feeling, the lyrics, the intent, the song and try to find where (or if) I can elevate or reveal or better frame the heart of what’s there. This is meant to be the flow state, moving intuitively and viscerally based on what’s coming out of the speakers. This is where efficiency in toolset matters -- where an extremely efficient human-computer interaction matters, where knowing your tools cold matters. I want to reduce latency between feeling and move and I don’t want anything to get in my way. 

So to answer your question: I think about ways to continue to be able to access and preserve that crucial flow state during the time where it matters the most. And it can manifest a million ways that aren’t directly related to mastering at all: taking a walk, working out, doing a J, listening to a new record, checking Discord, unplugging, whatever. And yes, sometimes it also means refining my template or my Streamdeck shortcuts or creating a new preset.

expert_substantive_messages.author: cian riordan
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Mixing Drums:

After now listening to many of Jon & Matt’s podcasts, as well as existing on this discord for a while, I’ve found myself feeling a little perplexed by people’s ability to mix things so fast. It finally clicked that many folks these days (especially in the pop world) are getting stems to mix from — not full multitrack sessions — and often not real drumsets/instruments in real rooms. In my world, for better or worse, I’m almost always getting multitrack files. So the prospect of only spending 2-3 hours on a mix is just impossible. That will often times barely get me past the drum sound! So for us mere mortals that are still stuck mixing real instruments, here’s my process for approaching drum mixing.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Ross Fortune
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Nailed it Will. Split mono is a step in my mix prep sequence. Efficient method goes like this:

PT Downmixer stock plugin is the one for this (it collapses stereo channels to mono) - flip the phase of one side in the GUI and save that as your user default. If you insert your Downmixer on a faux stereo track, it’ll immediately silence it, so you can happily split and delete what you don’t need. 

(Check the meters though, sometimes ambience or other subtle stereo info isn’t very audible unless cranked.)

If the stereo track contains slightly panned mono information, pushing/pulling either of the faders in Downmixer will quickly get it to cancel, and you can note how much extra gain you need to add or subtract when level matching in the final step (below). Obviously if it’s deliberately panned info, you can either just leave the track stereo or match the pan position by ear (I prefer to do this because I like mono channels to behave like mono channels, and also half the CPU you’d use on a stereo track).

Finally, use clip gain to add 3dB to the resulting mono channel, and obviously pan it centre. This makes up for the level change according to default pan laws in Tools (-3dB).

expert_substantive_messages.author: oaklandmatt
expert_substantive_messages.content:
i love this question. i've been doing this for long enough that the cycles of how records sound has changed several times. so every few years i try and take some time to unlearn/relearn.

there's no good short answer, but i'd start with taking some time outside of mixing to just listen to records. whether you've done this before or not, get to know your speakers and your monitoring environment better than before. listen to your favorite records that you know well, and make some tweaks. you don't necessarily have to redo your whole setup, but listen to your speakers in slightly different positions, different settings on the back of the speaker, etc. and really dig into listening and enjoy yourself.

that's usually enough to make me think about mixes very differently (which ultimately means i get better when i re-incorporate most of the things i already know). but if you need more, just try and simplify. start a mixing by just leveling everything. clip gain and leveling and panning. then balance frequencies and compress (via compressor or saturator or limiter or whatever). basically, with fresh ears, go back to basics.

not sure if that will transform you into a new mixer, but that's an outline of an approach i use when i feel like i need a big talent upgrade

expert_substantive_messages.author: BatMeckley
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Man. 85 percent of the tracks I’d get would require an hour of trying to line up the song PROPERLY to the grid. It’s not as easy as lining a kick to the grid as half you guys are using kick samples that have space before the transient.  When I’m out here nudging and stretching vocals at 1/1000th of second resolutions, which can dramatically change the pocket and vibe, it’s a kick in the teeth then if the whole track ends up being a tenth of a second off. 

The trick I came up with was putting four low frequency Square wave bursts maybe an 1/8th note long each at the beginning or end of each song. That means at no matter the master bus processing (or worse the mp3 meta data at the beginning pushing the song back) you can recalibrate EXACTLY the track back on to the grid. In that case, once you’ve figured that bit out, slap whatever you want on the bus. The square wave trick is how we were able to prove how logic or ableton was bouncing out of time even when a ton of people didn’t hear it or notice.

expert_substantive_messages.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_substantive_messages.content:
This is a constant in record making. Balancing your own thoughts with those of your client or collaborators. 

Cian is right on of course, but I’d encourage you not to think of it as binary. Almost always, there’s a version of their note that makes the song better, and it’s your job to hear it. 

In the end, it’s their record tho, and they’re the ones who will be playing it out, selling it, promoting it however they can… so they’re the ones who *need* to be happy with it in the end. 

My longtime producer & collaborator Jon Kaplan used to say “it’s your record, you can be wrong if you want to.” I give that to artists I work with now. Going in I tell them I’m going to treat you like an equal, until you tell me it’s your record and you can be wrong if you want to. 

Honestly that one idea has eased the tension on so many occasions for me.

expert_substantive_messages.author: oaklandmatt
expert_substantive_messages.content:
1. Sing a lot every day. If you don't, no other advice matters. Sing songs you like, sing in the shower, sing because you're now a singer. IN ADDITION TO THIS:

2. Hire a decent vocal coach and do a few vocal lessons (even a single lesson with a great teacher is important). You will get someone to teach you in-person how to breathe properly (that's the power source for the instrument you're learning). ALSO, you'll come away with a recording of a vocal warm up (somewhere between 5-20 minutes usually). YOU WILL THEN:

3. Start EVERY day with vocal warm ups.

4. Do whatever else you want to do that gets you singing a lot. Make it fun. I like learning songs, doing a voice memo every time I sing, and occasionally listening back. I sing bob dylan songs for my girlfriend. I record tons of vocals for songs I'm working on. Etc

expert_substantive_messages.author: Adam Thein
expert_substantive_messages.content:
I'm going to take a stab but it's a little picky on the terminology and it's long-winded:

Usually working with a mixer is like driving down a one way street in terms of file swapping.  You typically bring in a mixer when your song and production is fully complete, you've made it the best version of itself you could reach on your own but still want to bring in someone with more experience to help you take it to that next level of polish.  So typically in this version of a client/mixer relationship you probably wouldn't ever ask for the multitrack post-edit without some sort of unique circumstance that you'd be communicating with them directly.

It sounds to me in your other conversations here that in your case, the mixer is really filling a engineering/additional production role in your project.  They are taking files of yours before they can see the entire picture of the song and helping shape the tones, doing the editing, and managing the files for you as you submit more pieces to them over time.  In this type of working relationship files are typically shared in a two way street style.  You both are collaborating and working together toward the finish line.  This role is not something I would call a mixer though - they may still do your final mixes but they are also acting as an engineer or even producer.

I know this is being a little semantic but I think it's important because the context changes how you can describe it as customary or not.

As always, you'll need to chat directly to them and explain a bit why you want to get those edited multitracks back.  My first assumption sadly if I were in your buddy's shoes is that you weren't happy with the work and wanted to send those files to someone else.  So if that's the case, let them know early, and if that's not the case, let them know why you want the files.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Rollmottle
expert_substantive_messages.content: @kidcutler hit all the practical cons...running all the infrastructure to stand up a new structure is pricey. also, once you get the city or county involved, they'll want their cut and re-assess the property to include the new building for an updated tax basis. i would think about long term...would you purpose build a space that is specifically a studio? or would you just build a structure and make a studio inside? for re-sale, if it's a purpose-built studio, that certainly narrows the audience who would find a purpose-built studio a value-add to the purchase. if it's just a building that can be turned back into an ADU or garage easily, then that's an easier thing for most buyers to wrap their head around and probably a value-add. if you can build it as an ADU or garage, this might also change the way it's assessed. depending on the laws where you live, you might be able to get away with a building up to a certain square footage for "free." the way in which the building is classified might also make a difference. here in Glendale, CA, they've really loosened the ADU laws to encourage people to build to relieve pressure on a short-supply rental market. if you stay under a certain square footage, your tax basis does not change. i think it's a generally a great idea if you have the $$$$$$ and patience. if this is what you'll be doing for, well, your life, then it seems like a worthy investment to make.

expert_substantive_messages.author: LAPhill
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Noah covered a lot, but a few (also stream of consciousness) thoughts to add:

There is no formula to when to take the leap. It's helpful to have some money in the bank, because it's going to take awhile for things to start happening. The more connections you have, the more in-roads you've made, the easier it will be to drum up work in music and keep the lights on. The less responsibilities and overhead you have, the easier the beginning stages of freelance life will be.

Don't think about your music career in terms of the same metrics as your day job, you're burnt out on it for a reason. So instead of "am I making what I made before," think "can I survive on this for now?" and if not, "what will get me to a place that I can afford to pursue this dream?"

Any music job can be a boon for your career, and chances are you don't know where the opportunities will come from. The Beatles became the Beatles by playing cover songs at shady clubs, honing their sound and learning to play with each other. For someone else, that would've been a mindless, thankless gig with no upside. When they started playing better gigs, they were ready and stood out because of it.

How you do anything is how you do everything - if you're an intern at a studio cleaning up trash, you may be around huge artists and engineers. If they see you as dependable, friendly, going above-and-beyond, there's a tiny chance that a life-changing opportunity could emerge. Likewise, if they see you doing a sloppy job, that's how they're going to assume you'd be in the room, too.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Slow Hand
expert_substantive_messages.content:
What are you doing for chords? A common pitfall of static arrangements is getting locked into the same four bar chord loop. Sometimes you've got to break out of that. Start there, even if it's as simple as telling a different story with your chords over eight bars versus four bars.

Play with the harmonic rhythm of your chord changes. Some very basic examples:
1. Instead of a single chord every measure, alternate between one chord per measure and two chords per measure.
2. Hold on a single chord for six measures and then do a cadence with a quick succession of chords on bars seven and eight.
3. Take your progression and play it at half the speed (a four bar progression becomes an eight bar progression).

I know you said you're just making beats right now, but chords or a melody are going to inform and motivate your "players" and show them what to do. There needs to be some "meat" to the song for them to react to. If you don't like the melody you can mute it later. But give your "players" something to react to.

expert_substantive_messages.author: David Fuller
expert_substantive_messages.content:
To go into more detail... Unbalanced signaling like a guitar or a speaker input from an amplifier just has a signal lead (hot) and a common (ground). Speaker cables in particular do not use the common as shielding where unbalanced line level (like consumer RCA) and instrument level cables do. 
Balanced signaling like mics and pro audio line level equipment requires a "hot" signal, a "cold" signal (either polarity inverted hot or just nothing but with the same source impedance), and a common (ground/shield). At the receiving end of the connection, there is what's called a differential amplifier. Short version, a differential amp polarity inverts cold and combines it with hot, thereby reducing common mode noise by cancellation (and also some distortion, but we'll get back to that later).

expert_substantive_messages.author: Rollmottle
expert_substantive_messages.content:
The buffer has nothing to do with sample rate or fidelity of a given capture. Buffer only matters for the performance of your computer. For setting your buffer, you'll have to find the balance between latency and stability if you're recording. If you're mixing, raise the buffer until your system is stable. 

For sample rate and bit depth, you will be fine working at 48/24.

test pressings don’t work that way, the test pressing is to determine if the cut and plating has any problems, if it does all 5 of the pressings will have the same problems in the same spots.

What you need to do is sit and listen with a notepad noting the times of the “problems” you hear, on each pressing, then if all of them have the same issue, then you have a problem with the pressing.

If you know the cutting engineer that’s the best.

My cutting engineer said, “watch sibilance and take all loudness processing off, driver at -18 and you know then you’ll have a decent vinyl master.

expert_substantive_messages.author: cian riordan
expert_substantive_messages.content: If you have a mono sound on a mono track, it will sound mono. If you have mono sound on a stereo track, it will still sound mono. You can add delays, phasing, pitch shifting, etc to make it sound 'wide'... and yes, it will theoretically take up more space in the mix. As far as taking up more headroom, there's just too many variables to figure out there. But if you have the mono sound on a mono track, and the mono sound on a stereo track, with modern pan laws, they would both take up the same headroom.

expert_substantive_messages.author: LAPhill
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Are you looking for resources on writing/production, or mixing? Just like with the record side, there's so much noise from bedroom composers and people that have zero real-world experience. And as Ruairi is always saying, even the people with real success often can't teach what they know. Maybe I'm a bit cranky after an 8 hour delay at the airport yesterday, but Spitfire has gotten quite good at creating "tutorial" videos that are thinly veiled advertisements, and many of their libraries are the equivalent of one-knob plugins or CLA vocals. Selling paint-by-numbers solutions to naïve kids who want to get into scoring (They're far from the only ones guilty of this). But to focus on some of the channels I think are actually worth their salt:

8-Bit Music Theory: https://www.youtube.com/@8bitMusicTheory/videos
Can be a bit basic at times, but he talks a lot about structure which, IMO, is becoming a lost art in modern scoring.

Anne-Kathrin Dern: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWJg1w7F3PKPbSpEF2YOejVjWAg-KcM3Z
Not the biggest name out there, but she has a no-bullshit way of explaining things about orchestration and theory that is clear and concise. As far as "teachers," I think she's a good one.

Alan Meyerson Waves Sessions: https://youtu.be/h9jZqn5lnw4
I hesitate to include this. I know for a fact that Alan swapped out a bunch of his go-to plugins to make everything a Waves product. I haven't watched this in awhile, but it's a good insight into how he sets up a big mix session and why he makes some of his decisions. He's also playing to the camera/audience some, so this is a your-mileage-may-vary recommendation.

McGowen Soundworks: https://www.youtube.com/@McGowanSoundworks/featured
Phil knows his shit, and goes pretty deep breaking down a few actual mixes, which is pretty rare to find.

If I think of others, I'll report back. Hope that helps

expert_substantive_messages.author: Adam Thein
expert_substantive_messages.content:
A few more that I use constantly:

Cmd + K for Key Mapping (great for auditioning a chain)

In adaptive grid mode:
Cmd + 1 for more subdivisions in grid
Cmd + 2 for fewer subdivisions in grid
Cmd + 3 for triplet grid

Hold Cmd to override grid for selections and moving clips
Shift + Opt + Cmd and click and drag within a clip to slip audio within clip region

Shift + Cmd + R to enter export screen

For arranging things quickly shift modifier will add or remove time and move all automation.  For example:

Shift + Cmd + D = Duplicate and add time
Shift + Cmd + X = Cut time
Shift + Cmd + V = Paste copied time

expert_substantive_messages.author: Zack Hames
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Here goes…
Million ways to skin this cat. I’ll give you food for thought.

1. At least double track. My personal goal, is to get the sound to be as awesome and huge and perfect with 1 pair of guitar tracks doubled, with 1 mic on an amp. That’s the ideal scenario for me. That said There are people that sum 4 mics down to 1 signal on a mixer and it sounds amazing.  

2. The more performances  you add of the same part, the more blurry it will sound.if you need different textures, consider recording a DI so it can be blended in with your amp in any manner of your choice, either reamping, distorting with a plugin, whatever. (Check phase)

3. I like when the left and right are *subtly* different, no drastically different. You hear “the left and right being different is what makes something wide”
This is true. But I loathe when it’s so different it feels lopsided.

How do we address this? 

-double track using the same guitar so the tuning and intonation is most similar 

-change the amp head but keep the same cabinet/speaker so the overall EQ is similar but my the gain structure is different

If you use 2 different guitars, consider the scale lengths. This will change subtle intonation things, for better or worse.

expert_substantive_messages.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Short answer; it’s program dependent. And everything depends on everything. 

Long answer:

I spent a long time hoping MEs would answer these questions for me, but honestly not a one of them knows wtf they’re doing. Certainly not enough to quantify things like “how much louder will I make your track.”

Best thing I did along the way was develop relationships with MEs. Usually one at a time, and worked through my questions in real time. Figured out what happened when masters come back and i felt amazing vs when they come back and I felt just ok. 

Over time I’ve developed a philosophy for myself, (and while that changes/evolves over time,) I’m now confident when I send a mix to master that what I’ll get back will be a more finished  version of my ideas. And “more finished” is not necessarily correlated to “how loud.”

expert_substantive_messages.author: chrissorem
expert_substantive_messages.content: I can’t speak for Dr Luke,  @BatMeckley might be able to chime in here.  In my experience, on some occasions I have to ride the input gain between a verse or chorus if there is a large dynamic difference. I’d rather split that up if it’s an option for the singer but if it’s a live take you have to do whatever is necessary to make it sound great. Sometimes attenuating the output gain. Sometimes  i have my hands on the compressor input and output and I’m attenuating both. I like a 176 compressor for this as it’s  very forgiving in gain reduction. If I can’t manage any of the above I mult the vocal and have one safety track with the gain trimmed to a safe spot

Just taking the time to figure out the right changeover strategy and timing so that I could actually make the move once I basically had two fully functioning rigs stood up in parallel. My additional complicating factor is having a laptop that is a dupe of the studio rig, so keeping it all straight and everything in sync is a bit of a puzzle. 

I took the transition as the opportunity to phase out some mechanical drives so I had to get some new drives for the M4 instead of re-using the old Time Machine mechanical drive. The M4 mini only has Thunderbolt/USB C ports -- the M1 has USB A's and Thunderbolt/USB C's so I needed a TB hub to get my old USB hub to play on the M4. The move forced me to sort out my iLok strategy between my mastering rig and my production rig because it was quite messy (I ended up getting a 2nd iLok for the M4 to make things way easier between it and the laptop). It was just a lot of little stuff for me. If you're not changing machine form factors and it's mostly a software exercise, then it might be worth it.

expert_substantive_messages.author: cian riordan
expert_substantive_messages.content:
I'll gate everything with the Pro-G. Usually as tight as I can while sometimes automating threshhold to make sure ghostnotes don't get lost. I'll peel back the ratio once I have everything triggering properly to let some bleed in to taste. Sometimes I'll only gate 2-3 dB to just get something to pop. Sometimes its in a vaccum.
I will very rarely compress individual drum mics. And I pray that the recording engineer didn’t either. I like most of my compression to come from the busses. It sounds more natural to my ear and allows you to get away with a more compressed, exciting sound than just whacking the close mics. I’ll find at the beginning my drum mixes will be very ‘pokey’ — I want each drum to sound explosive and over the top. That way when i start compressing them, they maintain their transient quality when they start getting dynamically reduced.

I’m always cutting tons of 250-350 out of the kick drums and trying to manufacture any attack with saturation instead of EQ. Having a SansAmp or a Saturn plugin adding high end always sounds more natural to me than just additive EQ. I’m always very wary of the 2-5khz region, and find even-order harmonics are the best bet to fill in the blanks there.

I tend to like my snare drums warm, so often low-shelving down the super low end and keeping the 150-300 ‘boosh’ intact. I try to avoid using HPF on drum mics because at this point, things should be relatively in phase, so if I put a filter on, it’s going to throw the whole kaboodle off whack. Shelves are your friend here. And same as with the kick drums re: adding high end — I’m wary off adding the snap in the 2-5khz range, I’ll try and have the body of the snare drum really singing so I only have to add a little bit of top end, often above 5khz just for some air.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Zack Hames
expert_substantive_messages.content:
You would get 0 benefit using a TRS cable for guitar because it is an unbalanced signal. It would cost more money and time for 0 benefit. Also with certain connections it may NOT work. 

You probably know this, but active monitors just use balanced cabling with TRS or XLR connectors. Passive use proper speaker cables which are unshielded and TS.

Speaker cables don't have any shielding because they are expecting to see a super hot signal.  So this would result in unwanted noise in your guitar signal / active monitor signal because line level is much lower than speaker level.

So in all cases it's pretty much best to use the correct cable for the correct job. You'll save money and your equipment's longevity and reliability.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_substantive_messages.content: **Tiny TLDR** - Which sample rate you use is not a deal breaker, or even close. You can make a great sounding record at any sample rate. There are edge cases where it can make a meaningful difference but in modern Pop, Rock and Hip Hop production it’s not *that* important

expert_substantive_messages.author: Nomograph Mastering
expert_substantive_messages.content: __**TLDR**__ - So what to do practically in the real world? If I had a super fast and stable computer I would record, produce and mix at 96k. It’s subtly better in every way and you can introduce any of the “desirable” problems from lower sample rates at will. BUT BUT BUT….if there was even the tinniest chance that the rig would hiccup, or my drives would not access fast enough, or that I would have a glitch in a real session then I would absolutely start at 48k.

expert_substantive_messages.author: David Fuller
expert_substantive_messages.content: I don't consider it a good idea to work above 96 though, as you'll start introducing junk from switching power supplies, class D amps, noise shaping from D/A and A/D, etc into the program material. At lower sample rates it's effectively rolled out by extremely steep AA filters

expert_substantive_messages.author: David Fuller
expert_substantive_messages.content: Anyway: just work at 48, and stop asking me to change the clock to 44.1 because I know you'll forget to change it back after and the next person will be all confused why their session sounds wrong

expert_substantive_messages.author: Ross Fortune
expert_substantive_messages.content:
**General**

Interview style material can be great, and sources like Mix With The Masters where you can watch legitimate professionals working while they explain why they do what they do. Of course, you first need to understand the tools in order to understand why people use them in certain ways in specific situations, so building your knowledge of the fundamentals is important.

In general beware of anything with hyped titles like “30 MIXING HACKS I WISH I KNEW”. The internet is awash with misinformation, so it’s important to assess who the information is coming from, and what their agenda may be (whether that’s building subscribers, or shilling a product etc). If in doubt, research the records these people have worked on, and listen to them to see if you actually like how they sound!


**Engineering/Mixing/Production**

Steve Albini / Electrical Audio: https://www.youtube.com/@ElectricalAudioOfficial

Making records with Eric Valentine: https://www.youtube.com/@mrwev

Just For The Record - Mixing/interview streams - https://www.youtube.com/@JFTRLive

Sol State - Clips from longer form streams by (mostly electronic and pop) producers - https://www.youtube.com/@SolStateMusic

Live With Matt Rad (focused around Instagram Live interviews, with a generous community on Discord - generally skewing towards pop)

expert_substantive_messages.author: Slow Hand
expert_substantive_messages.content:
It sounds like a delay unit with a *freeze* function that captures the audio buffer and makes it repeat infinitely without decay or degradation. Soundtoys *Primal Tap* has this feature. You might be able to cheat it using a regular delay unit if you set the feedback amount to 100% and disable the filtering or modulation  in the feedback loop so that it doesn't degrade.

Also, that echo is drenched in a large reverb.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Slow Hand
expert_substantive_messages.content: Yup! *Delay* has it. If you click the infinity button (circled in red) it is the same functionality. It will freeze the buffer at a length equivalent to your delay time and not decay.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Slow Hand
expert_substantive_messages.content:
**Some More (cause you've got me thinking):**

Kick off the song with a bang.
Write a deliberate introduction. (This is big. It will give your record propulsion, confidence and purpose instead of dropping the listener into the middle.)
End the record in a conclusive and unmistakable way.

Everybody plays as soft as they can.
Everybody plays as loud as they can.
The louder you play the simpler the part has to be.
The softer you play the faster the part has to be.

Role play. Choose an emotion/mindset and embody that as the player: melancholy, furious, chaotic, childlike, meek.

Instrumental fills every few bars.
Take a solo. A short one.
Make some noise!

Listen to your song at different tempos.
Do a dramatic speed up or slow down - This will show you new aspects of your groove.

Unexpected part entrance.
Intro solo before the band enters.

Only two instrumental parts allowed. Be minimal and sparse.
Write a melody starting with the kick pattern.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Adam Thein
expert_substantive_messages.content:
I'd get in touch with a music lawyer who can help you make sure you have everything in place to collect all your back end - there's a lot of revenue sources you'll want to make sure you are collecting from.

Often you'll have had a producer agreement in place and a letter of direction that will be sent to the distributor/label so that if you have points on the master you'll be paid directly from them.

You'll also need to have a PRO/Publisher in place to collect songwriting royalties, and many folks have in place a publisher deal or publisher admin deal to collect those royalties on your behalf in exhange for a % of your royalty.  In my case I am set up with BMI in the US as my PRO and Publisher and have an admin pub deal with Sentric to collect in territories outside the US.

Also you'll want to be set up with SoundExchange to collect digital performance royalties (SiriusXM, iHeart, Pandora).  This often also involves the letter of direction that is kicked off with your producer agreement.

I'm probably forgetting something but I'd highly recommend talking with a music lawyer to get things set up and working for you.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Zack Hames
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Prophet 6 is like the be all end all for hardware synths. If I could recommend anyone that’s serious about synths or production In General and can afford it, this is the move. 

Otherwise, I’d go quality over quantity. Get a knobby analog synth that’s easy to make sounds quickly. You’ll have more fun if you’re used to more tactile instruments.

Having a digital synth with a bunch of menus that’s “more powerful” (3+ oscillators, several LFO’s, tons of polyphony) isn’t any fun when you can’t change the sounds quickly,easily, or intuitively. 

Korg MS20 was the first synth I fell in love with. Felt like playing guitar or something. Like an actual instrument.

Prophet 6 and OB-6 are incredible. If I had to pick one for myself it would be the OB-6. But the prophet is super versatile and usable in any style more so than the OB6.

I’d take an analog mono synth with knob per function over a powerful digital synth with menus

expert_substantive_messages.author: NoahNeedleman
expert_substantive_messages.content:
This isn’t for everyone, but a few big mixers like this technique. 

After you clean & clip gain, (RX is super helpful for plosives, mouth noises, de essing,) this is one of the only ways I know to take a vocal from raw to sounding like it was tracked well. 

The concept is mostly about balancing a spitty compressor like an 1176 and a slower/warmer compressor like a Fairchild, and then bussing both of those to a new aux, then eq’ing compressing saturating de essing like that was the vocal you weee given in the first place.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Slow Hand
expert_substantive_messages.content:
Phase shift on a single sound is rarely (if at all) noticeable. 

Phase shift on a sound becomes important when that sound interacts with a second sound. It’s about the relationship between them because it changes the constructive and destructive interference (phase cancellation) that occurs between the two sounds.

There may be a few instances where it matters in the context of a single sound, but I’ll let more qualfied people chime in on that.

expert_substantive_messages.author: Zack Hames

what you're saying makes sense. Couple things to try;

1. different click sound! I really like "marimba 2" in pro tools for some reason. really easy to hear always, feels REALLY on time.

2. Maybe try having a timed delay on one of your drum signals you can play off of. like a 1/16 note or triplet echo very faintly that, when you're in the pocket, grooves with your drumming. might be tough if you're doing really busy proggy stuff or if you're really worried about timing from an OCD perspective.

3. if you have scratch guitar/bass tracks that were tracked to a click/perfectly gridded drum thing, playing along to that is usually far more inspiring and you can rely less on the click because you can just listen to the instruments.

4. This is where having someone else record you helps. you might be totally in your head about this. a "producer" could be like "bro that take was legit perfect"
